We are delighted and humbled to announce Lu Yen-Hsun from Taiwan, better known as Rendy Lu, as a P6F Ambassador.

Rendy is a professional tennis player with a career high ATP ranking of 33 in 2010. He is also a current member of the #ATP Player Council. 
Rendy became the first Taiwanese player to reach a quarter-finals of a Grand Slam losing to Novak Djokovic at Wimbledon in 2010 but not before  defeating Andy Roddick in 5 sets in the previous match. 
Rendy is regarded as one of the nicest and perhaps most hardest working players on the ATP Circuit with a record 28 ATP Challenger Titles to his name. 
Most importantly, Rendy embraces the opportunity to give back to the community and shares the values of P6F in ensuring children are actively participating in sports and physical activity. Rendy has contributed his time significantly to projects in his home country of Taiwan as well as abroad including Cambodia where he has helped support P6F in delivering coaching courses and clinics. 
We are proud to have you on board and welcome to the P6F family!

Rendy has labral tear in the shoulder and underwent operation 
During winter training the end of last year, Rendy's shoulder injury re-surfaced. After diagnostic, it was determined to be labral tear. Normally this type of injury requires surgery. Considering Rendy's age plus the long 9-month recovery time, doctors recommended to go thru rehab instead. After several months of rehab, Rendy started practicing in early April and came back on tour. However, after the first round match at Seoul Challenger in early May, the shoulder pain came back. After a few weeks of therapy, the pain continued and Rendy had to withdraw from French Open. After discussing with agent Dirk Hordoff, physio Stefan Duell and French Open doctor, Rendy came to Munich in Germany to receive treatment from Dr. Peter Habermeyer, an expert in shoulder injury. Dr. Habermeyer recommended Rendy to get surgery to have better chance of full recovery. 
This week, Rendy just completed a successful surgery. Now Rendy starts the recovery stage and the process will be long, at least 9 months. This means Rendy will miss Wimbledon, US Open, and the Asian Games.

I inhale with the M-neb mobile of NEBU-TEC to keep me and my respiratory system fit. I train to be fit for the ATP World Tour throughout the season very hard. Shortly before the tournament I can not afford a failure due to infection. Especially on the road, for example in the airplane, it is very dangerous to get viruses and bacteria. Due to the low humidity on board the breathing system dries out. The contact with countless people during my travels to venues increases the risk of developing a respiratory infection enormous. Air conditioner in hotel rooms are on top also very dangerous to get sick. To avoid infection, prevent or treat I inhale therefore regularly with the M-neb mobile. The small and light inhaler accompanies me everywhere and anytime. This makes it for me an indispensable partner during my preparations, travels and competitions. Thank you to the company NEBU-TEC for the support! #Inhalation #Inhale #Prevention
